A ring (admitting a unit element) is a set R together with two laws of composition written as addition '+' and multiplication '.' such that: (i) R is a commutative group with respect to addition. (ii) R is a monoid with respect to multiplication, i.e., the multiplication is associative, and there exists a unit element in R. (iii) The distributive laws hold, i.e., (a+b) 
cdot c=a 
cdot c+b 
cdot c, and c 
cdot(a+b)=c 
cdot a+c 
cdot b for all a, b, c in R.
For ideals $\mathfrak{a}, \mathfrak{b}$ in a ring $R$, the sum $\mathfrak{a}+\mathfrak{b}$ is defined as $\{a+b ; a \in \mathfrak{a}, b \in \mathfrak{b}\}$.
Does the concept of a/an Ring need to be defined for a definition of a/an Sum of Ideals to make sense? (True if the first concept is needed and False if is not.)

Explanation: The definition of a Sum of Ideals explicitly mentions that the ideals are within a ring R. An ideal is a subset of a ring that is closed under addition and under multiplication by any element of the ring. Therefore, the concept of a ring is fundamental to the definition of an ideal. Without the concept of a ring, the notion of an ideal would not make sense, and consequently, the definition of a Sum of Ideals, which relies on the existence of ideals within a ring, would also not make sense. Thus, the concept of a ring is necessary for the definition of a Sum of Ideals to be meaningful.
